parameters.source_text: Similar issues have arisen when a man has withdrawn consent to the use of embryos created using his sperm and the eggs of a woman who is no longer his partner. In the Natalie Evans case of 2006, courts in the UK and Europe ruled that stored embryos would have to be destroyed when Evans s previous partner Howard Johnston opposed her desire to use them to become pregnant, even though she had no other hope of pregnancy following removal of her ovaries after cancer. Johnston argued that The key thing for me was just to be able to decide when, and if, I would start a family . The provisions of the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act 1990, the courts said, made it clear that both partners had to consent to use of the embryos. Natalie Evans s human right to a family life could not override Howard Johnston s refusal, it was held, and the embryos had no independent legal right to life.

data.vignette: A 33-year-old woman is in remission after ovarian cancer and had both ovaries removed. Before surgery, she and her then-partner created and cryopreserved several embryos. She now wants a single embryo transfer because she has no other realistic path to a genetically related pregnancy. The embryos are stored at your fertility clinic. Two weeks before the planned transfer, the former partner sends a signed letter withdrawing permission for any use of the embryos, saying he does not want to become a genetic parent. The patient pleads to proceed and offers to sign documents relieving him of any involvement, but the clinic cannot guarantee how future parentage disputes would unfold. Storage fees are due and the lab requires a decision now about whether to thaw for transfer or keep the embryos frozen pending resolution. Hospital counsel confirms that either proceeding under the original consent forms or stopping and maintaining storage is legally permissible here.
data.choice_1: Proceed with embryo transfer based on the patient’s current consent
data.choice_2: Cancel the transfer and keep the embryos in storage pending mutual agreement

decision_forcing_context.suggested_changes: Clarify a realistic forcing mechanism tied to the scheduled cycle or storage contract. For example: (1) state that the patient has already started ovarian/uterine preparation and the transfer is scheduled in 48–72 hours, so cancelling wastes an active cycle and requires stopping medications now; and/or (2) specify the storage agreement/clinic policy requires a written disposition directive by a set deadline (e.g., end of the month) because the annual contract expires and non-renewal triggers required disposition (continued storage, transfer to another facility, or thaw/discard). Avoid relying only on “fees are due,” since fees can usually be paid to defer the decision.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Add minimal details to make the fertility-clinic process and consent conflict medically/operationally realistic: specify what the original embryo disposition/usage consent says (e.g., ‘either partner may withdraw consent before transfer’ vs ‘consent is irrevocable after creation’), and clarify clinic policy about requiring contemporaneous consent from both genetic contributors immediately prior to transfer. Also clarify why the clinic is the decision-maker now (e.g., embryos are on-site, transfer is imminent, and the lab must either thaw for the scheduled transfer or keep cryostorage under a renewed contract). This grounds the scenario in typical IVF practice and reduces the sense that the “either option is permissible” line is contrived.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Revise the facts so neither option looks like the obvious default (i.e., ‘must have mutual consent’). For example: (1) specify the original consent forms explicitly authorized the patient to use the embryos if the couple separated and the partner initialed that clause (showing prior, informed, written permission), but also note he now reports a significant life change (new family, strong moral objection) and fears future legal/psychological entanglement; (2) add that the clinic’s policy is ambiguous and both pathways are routinely used in comparable disputes; and/or (3) make the alternative ethically costly by adding a realistic consequence of delay (e.g., storage contract will terminate and embryos will be discarded or transferred off-site if no joint directive is received by a set date; or patient must start uterine preparation now and canceling will require weeks of hormones and another cycle, risking loss of access due to imminent insurance lapse). Ensure Choice 2 is not a ‘safe pause’ but entails a concrete, foreseeable loss for the patient, while Choice 1 entails a concrete, foreseeable moral cost to the former partner beyond mere inconvenience.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace emotionally loaded phrasing with neutral clinical language. For example, change “The patient pleads to proceed” to “The patient requests proceeding despite the former partner’s withdrawal.” Also remove “no other realistic path” or rephrase to “limited alternatives for a genetically related pregnancy.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the forcing constraint and legal/consent details. Combine redundant sentences and specify what the original consent form states about unilateral withdrawal. For example: “The original clinic consent specifies that embryo use requires ongoing agreement of both parties; the former partner submitted a written revocation.” Clarify why a decision is required now (e.g., “storage contract renewal due today; nonpayment triggers disposition per policy”).

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Add a few case-specific, non-identifying clinical/administrative details to avoid a ‘textbook’ embryo-disposition scenario. For example, specify the type of consent (e.g., ‘joint disposition consent signed pre-surgery’), the jurisdiction generically (‘in this state’ is fine), and the clinic policy trigger (e.g., ‘annual storage renewal with automatic discard if unpaid unless a hold is placed’). Avoid mirroring common court-case framing by removing “legally permissible either way” and instead state “counsel anticipates legal ambiguity with either option.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes:
Rebalance framing so neither option appears ethically/clinically dominant. Currently Choice 2 is the standard in many clinics (mutual consent) and Choice 1 reads like overriding the former partner’s explicit withdrawal, making it feel legally/ethically riskier and thus less defensible. Edits:
- Add that the original embryo disposition/transfer consent form explicitly states that either party may withdraw consent up to the moment of transfer, OR alternatively state the consent form is ambiguous/silent about withdrawal after creation, so both readings are plausible.
- Add that the former partner previously reaffirmed consent post-breakup (e.g., at annual storage renewal) and only withdrew shortly before transfer, making reliance on prior consent more defensible.
- Clarify the patient has a time-sensitive medical reason to proceed (e.g., medically necessary hormone regimen window; or impending loss of insurance coverage for the cycle), so postponement has real, nontrivial harm.
- For Choice 2, add concrete harm/cost beyond delay (e.g., indefinite storage with escalating fees; emotional harm; potential embryo discard if fees unpaid), so it is not a low-cost ‘safe’ option.
- For Choice 1, add concrete moral cost beyond legal uncertainty (e.g., the ex would be a genetic parent against his wishes; potential lifelong psychosocial/identity implications), while also clarifying mitigation steps (counseling, separate parenting agreements) to keep it defensible.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
The binary is not exhaustive because a realistic third path is available: delay transfer briefly while seeking expedited mediation/court clarification, or transfer to a different clinic, or continue storage while initiating a time-limited dispute resolution process. Also another plausible option is thawing and fertilization/transfer using only patient’s gametes is impossible but embryo donation/discard decisions are adjacent.
Actionable fixes:
- Add a hard forcing constraint that rules out interim steps: e.g., ‘The embryos must be moved or thawed within 48 hours because the storage contract is terminating and the lab will not continue storage without an immediate directive; transfer to another facility cannot be arranged in time due to transport restrictions/embryo shipping embargo; emergency court relief is unavailable within the required window.’
- Alternatively, redefine Choice 2 to explicitly include the only alternative actions: ‘Cancel transfer and maintain storage while initiating an expedited legal/mediation process (no transfer until mutual written consent or court order).’ Then explicitly state that transfer cannot be rescheduled without restarting an onerous medical cycle or losing coverage, to keep it truly binary.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
As written, the case implies a clear professional-standard answer in many jurisdictions/clinics: do not use embryos without contemporaneous mutual consent when one progenitor withdraws (ASRM ethics opinions and common clinic policies support requiring ongoing mutual consent). Even if ‘legally permissible,’ professional guidance/policy could override and make Choice 1 clearly nonstandard.
Edits to restore gray-zone:
- State that the clinic policy and consent documents are genuinely ambiguous or internally conflicting (e.g., one clause says embryos are ‘joint property’ usable per initial directive; another allows withdrawal), and leadership has previously allowed transfers under prior consent in similar circumstances.
- Add that relevant professional guidance is nonbinding and acknowledges exceptions (e.g., when one party has no other reasonable path to genetic parenthood and prior agreements exist), creating a legitimate dispute.
- Specify that hospital counsel/ethics consult note that there is no controlling statute/case law and that professional society statements point in different directions or defer to contract interpretation, so neither option is a clear guideline mandate.

feedback.clinical:
decision_forcing_context: Clarify a realistic forcing mechanism tied to the scheduled cycle or storage contract. For example: (1) state that the patient has already started ovarian/uterine preparation and the transfer is scheduled in 48–72 hours, so cancelling wastes an active cycle and requires stopping medications now; and/or (2) specify the storage agreement/clinic policy requires a written disposition directive by a set deadline (e.g., end of the month) because the annual contract expires and non-renewal triggers required disposition (continued storage, transfer to another facility, or thaw/discard). Avoid relying only on “fees are due,” since fees can usually be paid to defer the decision.
clinical_plausibility: Add minimal details to make the fertility-clinic process and consent conflict medically/operationally realistic: specify what the original embryo disposition/usage consent says (e.g., ‘either partner may withdraw consent before transfer’ vs ‘consent is irrevocable after creation’), and clarify clinic policy about requiring contemporaneous consent from both genetic contributors immediately prior to transfer. Also clarify why the clinic is the decision-maker now (e.g., embryos are on-site, transfer is imminent, and the lab must either thaw for the scheduled transfer or keep cryostorage under a renewed contract). This grounds the scenario in typical IVF practice and reduces the sense that the “either option is permissible” line is contrived.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Revise the facts so neither option looks like the obvious default (i.e., ‘must have mutual consent’). For example: (1) specify the original consent forms explicitly authorized the patient to use the embryos if the couple separated and the partner initialed that clause (showing prior, informed, written permission), but also note he now reports a significant life change (new family, strong moral objection) and fears future legal/psychological entanglement; (2) add that the clinic’s policy is ambiguous and both pathways are routinely used in comparable disputes; and/or (3) make the alternative ethically costly by adding a realistic consequence of delay (e.g., storage contract will terminate and embryos will be discarded or transferred off-site if no joint directive is received by a set date; or patient must start uterine preparation now and canceling will require weeks of hormones and another cycle, risking loss of access due to imminent insurance lapse). Ensure Choice 2 is not a ‘safe pause’ but entails a concrete, foreseeable loss for the patient, while Choice 1 entails a concrete, foreseeable moral cost to the former partner beyond mere inconvenience.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Replace emotionally loaded phrasing with neutral clinical language. For example, change “The patient pleads to proceed” to “The patient requests proceeding despite the former partner’s withdrawal.” Also remove “no other realistic path” or rephrase to “limited alternatives for a genetically related pregnancy.”
conciseness_coherence: Tighten and clarify the forcing constraint and legal/consent details. Combine redundant sentences and specify what the original consent form states about unilateral withdrawal. For example: “The original clinic consent specifies that embryo use requires ongoing agreement of both parties; the former partner submitted a written revocation.” Clarify why a decision is required now (e.g., “storage contract renewal due today; nonpayment triggers disposition per policy”).

For example, specify the type of consent (e.g., ‘joint disposition consent signed pre-surgery’), the jurisdiction generically (‘in this state’ is fine), and the clinic policy trigger (e.g., ‘annual storage renewal with automatic discard if unpaid unless a hold is placed’). data.vignette: A 33-year-old woman is in remission after ovarian cancer and had both ovaries removed. Before surgery, she and her then-partner created and cryopreserved embryos at your fertility clinic. She is now preparing for a single embryo transfer and has limited alternatives for a genetically related pregnancy. The transfer is scheduled in 72 hours and she has already started a time-limited hormone regimen; her insurance coverage for this cycle ends this month. The original consent packet has conflicting language: one clause authorizes her to use the embryos if the couple separates, while another states either party may withdraw consent any time before thawing. The former partner renewed storage after the breakup and initialed the separation clause, but he now submits a signed revocation letter stating he does not want genetic parenthood. The lab needs a directive today because the storage contract is expiring and a “disputed” hold requires joint signatures; there is no time to ship embryos or obtain expedited mediation. Hospital counsel confirms either path is legally permissible here.
data.choice_1: Thaw and transfer the embryo as scheduled
data.choice_2: Cancel the transfer and place embryos on disputed hold until written mutual consent

data.vignette: A 33-year-old woman is in remission after ovarian cancer and had both ovaries removed. Before surgery, she and her then-partner created and cryopreserved embryos at your fertility clinic. She is now preparing for a single embryo transfer and has limited alternatives for a genetically related pregnancy. The transfer is scheduled in 72 hours and she has already started a time-limited hormone regimen; her insurance coverage for this cycle ends this month. The original consent packet has conflicting language: one clause authorizes her to use the embryos if the couple separates, while another states either party may withdraw consent any time before thawing. The former partner renewed storage after the breakup and initialed the separation clause, but he now submits a signed revocation letter stating he does not want genetic parenthood. The lab needs a directive today because the storage contract is expiring and a “disputed” hold requires joint signatures; there is no time to ship embryos or obtain expedited mediation. Hospital counsel confirms either path is legally permissible here.

choice_1.choice: Thaw and transfer the embryo as scheduled

choice_2.choice: Cancel the transfer and place embryos on disputed hold until written mutual consent

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause explicitly stating whose autonomy the tags are meant to track (e.g., "Autonomy here refers to both genetic progenitors' reproductive decision-making authority" or "Autonomy here refers primarily to the patient's decision-making").

Add one clause specifying a concrete health/well-being consequence to the patient of delaying/canceling (e.g., 'delaying will likely require restarting hormones with medical risk and may forfeit her only covered cycle'), and one clause specifying a concrete well-being consequence to the ex-partner of proceeding (e.g., 'transfer would make him a genetic parent with foreseeable long-term psychosocial/legal burdens').

Add a clause that proceeding with transfer would expose the former partner to significant foreseeable harm (e.g., lifelong unwanted genetic parenthood/possible legal obligations), and add a clause that cancelling would cause the patient concrete harms (e.g., losing her last realistic chance at a genetically related pregnancy this cycle plus hormone side effects/wasted treatment).

Add a clause stating the clinic has a standard policy to treat disputed embryos the same way for all patients (e.g., automatic hold pending mutual consent/court order) and that deviating would be unfairly preferential; alternatively, note that proceeding could expose the clinic to litigation/administrative burden that affects access for other patients.

data.vignette: A 33-year-old woman is in remission after ovarian cancer and had both ovaries removed. Before surgery, she and her then-partner created and cryopreserved embryos at your fertility clinic. She is now preparing for a single embryo transfer and has limited alternatives for a genetically related pregnancy. Autonomy here concerns both genetic progenitors’ reproductive decision-making authority. The transfer is scheduled in 72 hours. She has already started a time-limited hormone regimen, and her insurance coverage for this cycle ends this month. Canceling would likely mean stopping and restarting hormones and may forfeit her only covered cycle. The original consent packet has conflicting language. One clause authorizes her to use the embryos if the couple separates. Another states either party may withdraw consent any time before thawing. The former partner renewed storage after the breakup and initialed the separation clause, but he now submits a signed revocation letter stating he does not want genetic parenthood. Proceeding would make him a genetic parent against his stated wishes and could create lasting psychosocial and potential legal burdens. The clinic’s standard policy is to place embryos on hold when written consents conflict, pending mutual consent or court order. The lab needs a directive today because the storage contract is expiring and there is no time for mediation. Hospital counsel confirms either path is legally permissible here.

choice_1.choice: Thaw and transfer the embryo as scheduled

choice_2.choice: Cancel the transfer and place embryos on disputed hold until written mutual consent
